final_answer.precision_note: Answer given to 3 significant figures, limited by the concentration of NaOH (0.150 mol dm-3) which has the fewest significant figures.

method: First, calculate moles of NaOH used: n(NaOH) = c × V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × (23.40/1000) dm3 = 0.00351 mol. From the balanced equation (L40), 2 moles of NaOH react with 1 mole of H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351 / 2 = 0.001755 mol. Finally, calculate concentration of H2SO4: c = n/V = 0.001755 mol / (25.00/1000) dm3 = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Mole ratio from equation: 2 NaOH : 1 H2SO4 correctly applied.
Volume conversions: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3 and 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3.
Final concentration: 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3 verified.
